3. How to Use¶

  1. Obtain manufacturer documentation for your Modbus device indicating register definitions.
  2. Determine whether the device will be using RS-232 or RS-485 communication, and the settings for baudRate that will be used.
  3. Determine which register data parameters are relevant for your application requirements, and how those are presented.
  4. Decide which register data are to be captured in periodic reports, and at what interval that set of data is most useful.
  5. Decide which register data are time-critical and need to be captured in real-time with an alert.
  6. Create and save your config.dat config file using a text editor based on the template.
  7. Create your build package using Solution Studio.

3.1. Example Use¶

3.1.1. Create Your Configuration File¶

In this example we will be reading data from a weather station.

Manufacturer documentation: Lufft Compact Weather Sensor WS504

The WS504 requires some manual configuration to use RS-485 in Modbus mode, using 9600-8-N-1 serial. The default Modbus Slave address is 1, which will be our networkId=1.

Lufft Weather Station Modbus Communications

We are only connecting to one device, so we will set deviceId=1.

We find the registers of interest, which are all read-only values (registerType=analog) and all 16-bit signed integers (encoding=int16). The manufacturer document provides both the PLC base-1 address (register number) and the native register address, so we can use the latter as address and leave the default configuration plcBaseAddress=0.

Lufft Weather Station Modbus Registers Example

And we map them to parameters using paramId, registerType, address and encoding:

Configuration File Template¶
Data/Sensor Register Type Register Number Register Address Units Decoding Min Max paramId registerType address encoding
Air temperature Read-only (Input Register) 32 31 Celsius Factor 10, signed -500 600 1 analog 31 int16
Relative humidity Read-only (Input Register) 11 10 %RH Factor 10, signed 0 1000 2 analog 10 int16
Relative air pressure Read-only (Input Register) 15 14 hPa Factor 10, signed 3000 12000 3 analog 14 int16
Wind speed, average Read-only (Input Register) 87 86 km/h Factor 10, signed 0 2700 4 analog 86 int16
Wind direction Read-only (Input Register) 19 18 degrees Factor 10, signed 0 3599 5 analog 18 int16

We want to send:

  • All our parameters as a report (reportingId=1) every hour (interval=3600)
  • Also send an immediate alert (alertId=1) if the temperature (paramId=1) goes above 35 degrees Celsius and another alert when temperature returns below 30 Celsius. The manufacturer document tells us the Modbus register contains temperature in degrees Celsius with a factor 10, so our thresholds will be highON=350 and highOFF=300

In order to get real-time temperature alerts, we will set pollInterval=10 seconds.

Our resulting config.dat file looks like:

/* Example Modbus Proxy configuration for Lufft WS504 */
/* PORTS */
port=rs485;baudRate=9600;parity=none;mode=rtu
/* DEVICES */
deviceId=1;networkId=1;port=rs485;pollInterval=10;byteOrder=msb;wordOrder=msw;serialRxTimeout=1000;serialTxTimeout=1000;plcBaseAddress=0;retries=3
/* PARAMETERS */
/* Temperature in read-only register 32 */
paramId=1;deviceId=1;registerType=analog;address=31;encoding=int16
/* Humidity in read-only register 11 */
paramId=2;deviceId=1;registerType=analog;address=10;encoding=int16
/* Air Pressure in read-only register 15 */
paramId=3;deviceId=1;registerType=analog;address=14;encoding=int16
/* Wind speed in read-only register 87 */
paramId=4;deviceId=1;registerType=analog;address=86;encoding=int16
/* Wind direction in read-only register 19 */
paramId=5;deviceId=1;registerType=analog;address=18;encoding=int16
/* REPORTS */
reportingId=1;interval=3600;paramIds=1,2,3,4,5
/* ALERTS */
alertId=1;paramId=1;maxON=350;maxOFF=300;paramIds=1,2,3,4,5

3.1.2. Create Your Build Package¶

Note

Use of the tools described below requires that you have a PC with a modern version of Windows OS.

  1. Download the latest Modbus Proxy package file from TBD or contact your Inmarsat Representative. Make sure you select the correct build for IDP or ST terminals.

  2. Download the latest terminal firmware package for your terminal model from ORBCOMM or contact your Inmarsat Representative.

  3. Download and install the latest Developer Toolkit from ORBCOMM or contact your Inmarsat Representative.

  4. Open Solution Studio from the Developer Toolkit

    1. Select Add, browse to the firmware package file and add it.
    2. Select Add, browse to the Modbus Proxy package file and add it.
    3. Select Modbus in the Services pane, then click Properties

    1. Select Add then select 004 - defaultMsgBitMap and set the value to 04 to enable timestamp on reports and alerts

    2. Return to the main GUI window by clicking OK when prompted.

    3. Click Edit, then click Add and browse to your config.dat file. Click OK until you return to the main window.

    4. Select Edit ‣ Core Service Properties then set the following similar to defaultMsgBitMap above:

      • Service ‣ 016-system –> 001 - executionWatchdogTimeout ==> 30000
      • Service ‣ 016-system –> 003 - autoGCMemThreshold ==> 5
      • Service ‣ 023-log –> 031 - traceSuppress3 ==> 1B 14

    5. Click OK until you return to the main window.

    6. Select Edit ‣ Post-Load Commands and type the following, depending on your terminal model:

      Post-load Commands (when using RS485 for Modbus)¶
      IDP series ST series
      trace channel main
      trace baud 9600
      trace enable
      log channel main
      log baud 9600
      log serial enable

    7. Select File ‣ Export Package and save the resulting build file e.g. my_modbus.idppkg.

    8. Select File ‣ Export Message Definitions and save the resulting my_modbus.idpmsg file.

    9. Save your Solution Studio file e.g. my_modbus.idpsln.

    Tip

    Best practice would be to use a file naming convention that includes a version and/or date.

3.1.3. Install Your Package¶

  1. Connect to your terminal’s main serial port using Console from the Developer Toolkit. Ensure your terminal is powered up.

  2. Select File ‣ Open ‣ Open Connection then select your COM port and Baud rate (default 9600). Click OK.

  3. Confirm that you see a shell>, #, or boot# prompt.

    Tip

    You may need to power cycle the terminal to get the boot loader message, then send 2 break (CTRL-B) commands within 5 seconds to get the boot# prompt.

  4. Drag and drop your build package onto the black area of the screen. Confirm that you see it begin the load process.

    • If prompted to Format the flash file system, select OK.

    Format the flash file system

    • Wait for the progress bar to complete.

    Loading the package file using Console

    • If you see the # prompt, enter the command start.

  5. If you are running Modbus on the main rs232, you will see a detaching shell message, then strange characters.

    Tip

    You can set up trace/log output on a spare serial port of the terminal. For example, use rs232 for trace when rs485 is connected to your Modbus device.

  6. Connect the configured serial port to your Modbus device.

3.1.4. Create Message Definition File¶

  1. Contact your Inmarsat Representative to send your idpmsg file to have merged with default message definitions.

3.1.5. Uplode Message Definition File to Inmarsat Message Gateway¶

  1. Your service provider can upload/associate the message definition file to your IsatData Pro mailbox and provide your authorization credentials for OTA API use.

3.1.6. Retrieve Data Using the IsatData Pro Messaging API¶

  1. Visit Inmarsat Developer Portal
